metadata.title: Gender antagonism and class conflict: Exclusionary strategies of male trade unionists in nineteenth-century Britain

relevance.topic: Gender antagonism and class conflict in labor markets
relevance.relevance: The study explores how male trade unionists in 19th-century Britain used exclusionary strategies against women in the labor market, which is relevant to understanding labor displacement due to technological change and gender dynamics.

independent_variables: introduction of women into male-dominated trades

dependent_variables.displaced: Male workers in various trades were displaced by the introduction of women workers.
dependent_variables.unemployment_or_underemployment: Male workers faced unemployment or had to seek work in other sectors when women were introduced into their trades.
dependent_variables.wage_changes: Women were paid significantly lower wages than men for the same work, leading to wage suppression.

text_fragments: 'Rivals of Men! Why should they be rivals? Why not co-workers?'
'The low price of female labor made it the most profitable as well as the most agreeable occupation for a female to superintend her own domestic establishment.'
qualitative_data.narrative_descriptions: The study describes how male trade unionists in 19th-century Britain used exclusionary strategies to prevent women from entering their trades, driven by a combination of gender antagonism and class conflict.

historical_context.economic_conditions: Industrial transformation and economic competition in 19th-century Britain.
historical_context.institutional_context: Trade unions and labor movements were significant in shaping employment practices and gender roles.

outcomes.main_findings: Male trade unionists in 19th-century Britain employed exclusionary strategies against women to protect their jobs and wages, driven by gender antagonism and class conflict.
outcomes.conclusions: The exclusion of women from certain trades contributed to gender-segregated employment, which remains a feature of the labor market.
outcomes.long_term_impacts: The study suggests that exclusionary practices contributed to long-term gender segregation in the labor market, which continues to affect wage equality.
